posts.title: Calling All Jellicles: Book Recs for T. S. Eliot's Cats
posts.text: Are we really about to recommend books to fictional cats? You bet your sweet Skimbleshanks we are.

posts.title: Move Over, Beach Reads: It's Time for Winter Solstice Books
posts.text: Winter is the best time for books. We're offering up a few book suggestions to help you deal with the cold and darkness in body, mind, and spirit.

posts.title: Reading the 2020 Awards Season: Golden Globes Edition
posts.text:
Nominees for the 2020 Golden Globes were announced this week, and the Hollywood Foreign Press Association has picked out a bookish bunch! 
Read up on the originals before the awards are announced on January 5 of the new year.

posts.title: Celebrating Emily Dickinson, Poetry's Favorite "Nobody"
posts.text: Her life has inspired a wide range of material, from speculative novels to illustrated children's books to an examination of her plants.

posts.title: Joseph Bruchac's Legacy: Picture Books for Thanksgiving and Beyond
posts.text: Bruchac has been writing for over 40 years, and he’s authored dozens of picture books for children about indigenous peoples' folklore and traditional stories, as well as nonfiction, plays, mysteries, and novels for older kids, teens, and adults.

posts.title: Where to Start with Margaret Atwood
posts.text: Her work is so varied and diverse that we’ve organized this where-to-start post by reader types.

posts.title: Reading the Clouds Away: Book Suggestions for Sesame Street Characters
posts.text: We want to honor our favorite residents of the best street in New York City…how else? With books.

posts.title: Required Reading for the Full 'Let It Snow' Experience
posts.text: After you read the original, check out a few more suggested novels by the three authors—and wait for the wave of YA book-to-screen adaptations to sweep up even more books in its swelling tide.

posts.title: 9 Books for Native American Heritage Month
posts.text: November is Native American Heritage Month, and the perfect time to pick up recent books by and about indigenous people.

posts.title: Hocus Pocus, Practical Magic: Which Books Should Our Favorite Movie Witches Read?
posts.text: Book recommendations for the wild, wonderful characters of our favorite Halloween films—witches and non-witches alike.

posts.title: Can't Get Enough Urban Fiction? Try These 20 Books.
posts.text: Because of the genre's fast pace and compulsive readability, many readers burn through urban fiction at a breakneck speed—meaning libraries are left with empty shelves and readers have to search other sections for books that have a similar subject matter, pace, and tone.

posts.title: Check Out the National Book Award Finalists for 2019
posts.text: It's October, and everyone knows what that means... time for the National Book Awards! This morning, the National Book Foundation announced this year's finalists in fiction, nonfiction, poetry, translated literature, and young people's literature.

posts.title: Fall Staff Picks for Kids
posts.text: Just as leaves turn in the fall, so do The New York Public Library’s Staff Picks, offering a new harvest of books our expert librarians recommend for kids of all ages.

posts.title: Kids Books for Rosh Hashanah & Yom Kippur
posts.text: Check out some of our favorite picture books for the start of the Jewish new year, and l'shana tova (happy new year) to all!

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: YA Fiction
posts.text: The New York Public Library's Best Books for Teens list doesn't come out until November, but the committee of YA staff members is hard at work reading as many 2019 titles as they can get their hands on. Here's some new fiction that's on their radar.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: Kids' Books for All Ages
posts.text: Our committee of dedicated library staff members are closing in on the finalists for our annual Best Books for Kids list! No promises about which titles will make the final cut, but check out some of the books they're debating right now.

posts.title: Celebrating the City's First Puerto Rican Librarian, Pura Belpré
posts.text: Pura Belpré was a legend in her own time—and in ours, as well.

posts.title: Fall Staff Picks
posts.text: Twilight is coming earlier, dawn is coming later, the hot garbage smell is finally fading from the streets of Midtown Manhattan ... and that means only one thing: It's autumn in New York. With the new season comes our new round of Staff Picks— 100 titles that NYPL staff members are excited to be reading right now.

posts.title: 9 Books That Are Emotional Roller Coasters
posts.text: August 16 is National Roller Coaster Day (yes, really), so we asked our NYPL book experts: What’s your favorite book that’s an emotional roller coaster?

posts.title: Bunny, I Love You!: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 146
posts.text: Gwen and Frank do a deep dive into the dark comedy, "Bunny" by Mona Award.

posts.title: Title Quest 2019: Finding Forgotten Titles Together
posts.text: NYPL librarians made more than 50 educated guesses at forgotten book titles! Here's a sample of some of the books that were found during #NYPLTitleQuest.

posts.title: Six Fun Facts about Beatrix Potter, Sheep Farmer
posts.text: We've picked out just a few facts about Potter that may surprise you. (Spoiler alert: The rabbit hole ends at Kate Middleton!)

posts.title: The Dog-Eared Days of Summer: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 145
posts.text: Do you dog-ear? Use bookmarks or sticky notes? Write notes in margins? Or do you—heaven forbid—underline? We delve deep into the ethical implications of leaving your mark on library books. Plus: two new summer reads and one musical cue.

posts.title: We're Not Lion... 13 Picture Books about Large Felines
posts.text: Whether you're psyched for the new Lion King movie or you're staying loyal to the original, remembering the story of Simba and his pals made us want to share some literary love for lions. We asked our book experts to recommend their favorites.

posts.title: More of Our Favorite Fictional Librarians, Ranked... Again!
posts.text: We wrote a blog post that ranked some of our favorite fictional librarians. We chose half a dozen and assigned scores that were definitely not arbitrary at all, and then … readers had a lot of opinions, so we've followed up on the original six with eight more.

posts.title: The Katniss Konundrum: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 144
posts.text: To prequel or not to prequel? Frank and Gwen debate the new installment of the Hunger Games franchise and two very different books about life in two very different places.

posts.title: Summer Reading 2019 | Book Lists for Adults
posts.text: It's a great time for adults to mix up their reading, too—whether you're hunting down a classic beach read (even if you're stuck in the city) or finally cracking open that giant biography you've been meaning to get to for ages.

posts.title: Are You There, Frank? It's Me, Gwen: The Librarian Is In Podcast
posts.text: Our next Summer Reading Challenge episode will be Aug. 8, and we'll be tackling Bunny, a brand-new blend of horror, fairy tale, and black comedy by Mona Awad.

posts.title: Summertime, and the Staff Picks Are Breezy...
posts.text: Our newest round of Staff Picks—more than 100 titles that we're excited about right now—is ready for prime time! Whether you're lying on the beach or stuck on the L train with no a/c, you'll find something cool on this list.

posts.title: Kids' Books to Celebrate Juneteenth
posts.text: Juneteenth has inspired literature for adults, including Ralph Ellison's classic novel of the same name, but there are also great books to introduce the holiday's stories and traditions to the youngest readers.

posts.title: LGBTQ Historical Fiction, 20 Years Before Stonewall
posts.text: Gay, lesbian, and bisexual characters come to the forefront in these eight books, which are set two decades during the two decades immediately preceding before Stonewall. Their novels were sometimes about secrecy and hiding, but also sometimes about coming out, empowerment, and asking questions or finding answers about sexuality.

posts.title: #WaltWhitman200: Walt Whitman Takes Over NYPL Instagram for His 200th Birthday
posts.text: Walt Whitman turns 200 today! In addition to The New York Public Library's exhibition called Walt Whitman: America's Poet, we're also giving Whitman control of NYPL's Instagram to celebrate his birthday.

posts.title: DIY ASMR, Library-Style: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 143
posts.text: This episode is brought to you by our soon-to-be-rival podcast, dreamed up by YA librarian Crystal Chen—who's also this week's guest! All rights reserved by her! We talk musicals, poetry, what it really means to create a list of "best" books, and professional development for library staff members.

posts.title: Fantasy Books Beyond Game of Thrones
posts.text: Rumor has it that a couple people weren't thrilled with the finale of a certain long-running TV series recently, so we thought it might be a good time to offer up some contemporary books that approach fantasy from a different perspective.

posts.title: Comfort Reads: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 142
posts.text: Gwen and Frank tackle one book that feels comforting and homey; one that's distinctly unsettling; and one that's somewhere in between. Plus: A stranger on the train helps us deconstruct the genius of J-Patt.

posts.title: Quiz: How Well Do You Know Foodie Kidlit?
posts.text: We picked a few examples of our favorite food-focused picture books and decided to test your knowledge of the culinary delights therein.

posts.title: Carla Hayden Wants You to Read a Book: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 141
posts.text: Dr. Carla Hayden sits down with Gwen and Frank to discuss what it really means to lead the Library of Congress—which, by the way, isn't only FOR Congress. Plus: lessons she learned from storytime, how she organizes her home library, and the first time she ever saw herself reflected in a book.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: Fresh Picture Books for 2019
posts.text: Check out our first 2019 roundup of brand-new picture books being hotly debated by our Best Books for Kids committee.

posts.title: Reading Stonewall: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 140
posts.text: It's the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall Riots, and Jason Baumann—NYPL curator and Grand Marquessa of All Things Stonewall—joins Gwen and Frank to discuss the Library's new anthology about the uprising and its role in the LGBTQ civil rights movement. And then he walks us through some yoga breathing, and it's legit.

posts.title: Eight Solid Staff Picks for Kids
posts.text: In honor of the 100th anniversary of Children's Book Week—and the wonderful organizing principle that every child can be a reader—we wanted to pull out a few selections from our Staff Picks.

posts.title: Call Your Librarian: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 139
posts.text: Aminatou Sow, writer and co-host of the popular podcast "Call Your Girlfriend," talks with Gwen and Frank about poetry, the mental treadmill of the Internet, and her childhood best friend: the librarian.

posts.title: Our Favorite Animal Stories
posts.text: We asked our favorite NYPL book experts to recommend their favorite children’s book—picture books through middle-grade—about a creature that is NOT a cat or a dog.

posts.title: 'A Small, Portable Truth': NYPL's Poem in Your Pocket Day 2019
posts.text: We're inviting patrons—in our branches all over the city and anywhere you are online—to take a breath, take a break from the news, and take a poem.

posts.title: Heartland, Homeland: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 138
posts.text: What makes a place home? Frank follows a book rec from a listener and discovers a powerful memoir that makes him rethink the American dream. Gwen's book is a new fairytale retelling... sort of... that involves feudalism and magical gingerbread and... well, maybe you should just have a listen.

posts.title: Books to Celebrate Immigrant Experiences
posts.text: To celebrate the rich diversity of stories that touch on immigration, our Selection and Readers Services teams compiled a list of recently published books—fiction, nonfiction, and poetry—about immigrant experiences.

posts.title: Are you – Nobody – too? The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 137
posts.text: Our poetry bonanza has arrived! In this episode—titled to pay homage to Frank's favorite Emily Dickinson stanza—he and Gwen get to read and hear poems suggested by their listeners.

posts.title: 2019 Bernstein Awards Finalist Spotlight: Amity and Prosperity
posts.text: The last featured finalist for the 2019 Helen Bernstein Award is journalist Eliza Griswold's book, Amity and Prosperity: One Family and the Fracturing of America. It's a multi-layered portrayal of what happened when the fracking industry came to one Appalachian town.

posts.title: Breaking the Mold: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 136
posts.text: Gwen and Frank meet a handful of characters who aren't bothered by what other people think. Plus: the pros and cons of reading reviews, the extra voice in translations, and the no-person's-land between picture books and middle-grade fiction.

posts.title: #PocketPoems: NYPL's Celebration of National Poetry Month
posts.text: To celebrate National Poetry Month, The New York Public Library has collected poetry from over 30 contemporary poets and staff members, with some writing especially for this project.

posts.title: Reading (or Not) as a New Parent: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 135
posts.text: How on earth can you read when you have a newborn? Stephanie Anderson—a new mom and a professional book selector for NYPL and the Brooklyn Public Library—comes to talk about the shifting habits of a readers with a new baby. Plus: Frank channels Supernanny! Again.

posts.title: The Gods Are Alright. But the Humans... The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 134
posts.text: Greek mythology and contemporary fiction join forces this week! Gwen and Frank read two books that make readers ask, what would you do—or, what should you do?

posts.title: Dance Your Books Off: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 133
posts.text: Okay, what's the deal with librarians and musical theater? This week's guest, newly minted children's librarian Kevin Kelley, traces his origin story back to the stage. He also discusses kids' books about the queer experience and offers up a brand-new first for the guessing game.

posts.title: Spring Staff Picks, 2019 Edition
posts.text: NYPL's stable of book experts has been reading, reading, reading throughout the winter, and they're ready to recommend their favorites!

posts.title: Playing the Long Game with Lorde and Parker: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 132
posts.text: Audre Lorde and Pat Parker were close friends who fought fiercely for social justice. In this episode, Frank and Gwen discuss a powerful book of letters between the two Black feminist poets.

posts.title: The Bernstein 2019 Shortlist: Meet the Finalists for NYPL's Journalism Award
posts.text: Check out the five books that topped this year's list for The New York Public Library's esteemed journalism prize, Helen Bernstein Book Award for Excellence in Journalism.

posts.title: One Book, One New York 2019
posts.text: Check out the five finalists for this year's One Book, One NY, the country's largest reading program, which aims to bring New Yorkers together to read the same book at the same time.

posts.title: 9 Books to Delight Your Inner Word Nerd
posts.text: Around here, every day is National Grammar Day, so we're presenting books that celebrate language in all its complicated glory.

posts.title: Library, Meet Bookstore: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 131
posts.text: Get rowdy with Roxanne Coady, indie bookstore owner and host of the Just the Right Book podcast. Roxanne finds common ground with Frank and Gwen, talking about places where people seek connection and community with books at their heart.

posts.title: The Librarian Is ALL IN: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 130
posts.text: Gwen's quest to learn more about Carol Channing took both her and Frank to a place where divas and dames truly reign—Broadway! Plus: Frank's book taps into the cultural obsession with visiting the past (repeatedly) to figure out the future, leading us into the arms of "Russian Doll" creator Natasha Lyonne.

posts.title: Curatorial Curiosities: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 129
posts.text: Books have lives too! Frank and Gwen take a break from talking about the words on the page and get into the stories of items in NYPL's archives. In this specially curated tour, meet the Mary Poppins doll that made peace between author and illustrator, hear about a woman spymaster during the Civil War, and find out what limp vellum is. Plus: Nancy Drew has a secret.

posts.title: The Evolution of Joy: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 128
posts.text: . . . or the joy of evolution? Frank's book traces the whole history of humankind and Gwen's is a short narrative about big changes. Plus: You can't talk about joy without talking about Christine Baranski. It's the law.

posts.title: Love & Resistance: LGBTQ Memoirs
posts.text: As we look back at the legacy of Stonewall, we wanted to recognize some LGBTQ+ writers talking about their own experiences, in their own words.

posts.title: Stonewall: Core Reading for the Past, Present, and Future
posts.text: To learn more about Stonewall specifically, and the history of LGBTQ activism in general, check out these core texts from the Library’s collections.

posts.title: Quarterbacks? Try QuarterBOOKS.
posts.text: Whether it’s between the pages or the goalposts, generational matchups will always capture the public's imagination.

posts.title: Time(less) Travel: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 127
posts.text: Book synergy abounds! Frank rediscovers Anne Frank's diary in a newly released graphic novel, Gwen becomes obsessed with a group of time-traveling historians, and everyone absorbs the small details of day-to-day lives during World War II.

posts.title: Celebrating Agatha Christie, Master of the Literary Twist
posts.text: We asked our NYPL book experts: Which Christie book is your favorite? What’s a good place to start for readers who haven’t read her books before? Are there any hidden gems that don't get enough attention, or super-popular books that don't get the credit they deserve?

posts.title: Don't Worry, Be Mary Oliver: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 126
posts.text: Frank and Gwen celebrate the life and work of Mary Oliver by reading a handful of her poems and doing something she might approve of—letting it all go and singing about dogs.

posts.title: Keep It Crafty with the Library
posts.text: For a novice, library resources could hold the key that unlocks your inner crafter. For an experienced DIYer, our books, digital magazines, and databases can help you expand your skill set and open up new frontiers.

posts.title: Remembering Poet Mary Oliver
posts.text: Oliver's work shares a certain clarity, a deftness with language that makes her poems easy to read and understand as well as deeply meaningful.

posts.title: Mourning Heathcliff, Hedwig, and All the Literary Dogs: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 125
posts.text: Have you ever truly grieved over the loss of someone in a book? Together with Eric Molinsky, host of the Imaginary Worlds podcast, Frank and Gwen dive into the psychology of readers' responses to character deaths. Don't worry, it's not as depressing as it sounds! Maybe!

posts.title: New Fiction! New Fiction! The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 124
posts.text: Gwen gets fired up about reading—you guessed it—new fiction this year, while Frank dips into the backlist of a new favorite author. Plus: New Year's resolutions, The Bachelor, and the best short stories of 2018.

posts.title: Finally! Read That Book You Always Meant to Start (or Finish).
posts.text: Tips and tricks to help you meet your reading goals—to hack your TBR pile, conquer your literary Waterloo, or tackle that elusive book you've always been meaning to read.

posts.title: How to Read Harder in 2019
posts.text: Every December, our friends at Book Riot come up with a list of 24 brand-new reading tasks for the brand-new year. Staring down that list of categories can be daunting, so we're offering up some ideas for a convenient place to start.

posts.title: Glory Edim Is Just Getting Started: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 123
Our Favorite Fat-Positive Reads
posts.text: We asked our book experts here at NYPL for their favorite fat-positive reads, and they came up with more than a dozen works of fiction, nonfiction, a yoga guide, and even a graphic novel. Check them out and, as Willowdean says, go big or go home.

posts.title: Pitch Imperfect: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 122
posts.text: Aca-scuse me? It's an impromptu celebration of our favorite feel-good a capella movie... and, oh yeah, some book recommendations, too. Frank goes for a soul-searching memoir about spirituality and religion, and Gwen suggests a fantastical flipbook for kids.

posts.title: The 12 Days of Bookness 2018
posts.text: It's time for The New York Public Library's second annual celebration of our entirely made-up bookish holiday!

posts.title: The Librarian Is LIVE: Podcast, Ep. 121
Which Dewey Decimal Number Are You?
posts.text: Check out our extremely unscientific quiz and find out which Dewey heading you fall under!

posts.title: Anger Is a Gift: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 120
posts.text: Aristotle famously (er, probably) said that anger is a gift, and Gwen's been given one this year: Rebecca Traister's book about the power of women's rage. Plus: Frank finds more presents in the New Yorker archives, and NYPL announces its year-end Best Books lists.

posts.title: Check Out This Sculpture: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 119
posts.text: We're obsessed with libraries loaning unconventional items: seeds, toys, tools, clothes, games, museum passes... and sculptures. Local artist Wendy Richmond joins Gwen and Frank to talk about her work and her new installation, which encouraged patrons to take home her incredible sculptures of her own hands.

posts.title: Keeping You Company in the Kitchen: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 118
posts.text: Whether you're cooking turkey for 20 or opting out of Thanksgiving entirely, books about food are always in season. Frank and Gwen talk about their favorite cookbooks and chef memoirs with NYPL's resident foodie, Jeanne Hodesh, and offer some family recipes of their very own.

posts.title: Introducing NYPL's Best Books of 2018
posts.text: The New York Public Library is thrilled to announce our Best Books of 2018, a curated selection of recommended reads for kids, teens, and adults, selected by our expert librarians!

posts.title: Read the 2018 National Book Award Finalists (and Winners!)
posts.text: Today the National Book Foundation announced the 2018 National Book Award Finalists for fiction, nonfiction, young people's literature, poetry, and translated literature. Explore the list of finalists, and check out the titles from The New York Public Library.

posts.title: Pop-Culture Storytime (with Garfield): The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 117
posts.text: What makes a good story time? Anthony Murisco, youth librarian extraordinaire, joins Frank and Gwen to talk all things kids and books. Plus: everyone's favorite lazy cartoon cat, a true stumper of a guessing game, and a flurry of pop-culture recommendations.

posts.title: Still Miss Harry Potter? Here Are 14 Books That Might Help.
BiblioSmiles: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 116
posts.text: A library podcast about a book about libraries? Sign us up! Frank goes meta this week with an in-depth review of Susan Orlean's new page-turner, and Gwen sees an author of children's classics in a new light.

posts.title: Celebrating the Best Illustrated Children’s Books of 2018
posts.text: This award—given jointly by The New York Public Library and The New York Times—honors the unimaginably talented illustrators who give kids yet another reason to love reading. We couldn’t be more excited about this collaboration or more proud of this list of gorgeous picture books.

posts.title: The Librarian Is In... the Voting Booth! Podcast Ep. 115
posts.text: It's almost Election Day. Do you know where your voting rights are? Christopher Famighetti, professor at Jefferson Market University, joins Frank and Gwen for an in-depth convo about voting — and what libraries have to do with it. Plus: a different take on Tolstoy and the surreal films of Luis Buñuel.

posts.title: Spooky Books for Kids: The Ultimate Creepy Guide
posts.text: It's Halloween, and your friendly neighborhood librarians are here to recommend their favorite eerie reads for kids. From gently mysterious to genuinely terrifying, scary stories are the order of the day.

posts.title: This Is Not the Foe You're Looking For: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 113
posts.text: Gwen and Frank tackle a near-future dystopian novel about space colonization and a sobering book about the fallacy of modern philanthropy. Plus: why pho is objectively the best food ever.

posts.title: Our Favorite Boston Books, Presented Reluctantly
posts.text: As we swallow our pride and set our sights on next year, we present recommendations of our favorite books set in Beantown. Enjoy your bagels, Boston Public Library. We'll see you in the spring.

posts.title: Hot Topix Galore: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 111
posts.text: Frank and Gwen are all about feminist texts this week. They go back in time with the classic short story, "The Yellow Wallpaper" — which is also NYPL's newest Insta Novel — and then hit the present (hard) with Red Clocks. In between, there's a beautiful picture book for kids. Plus: Frank figures out a literary puzzle.

posts.title: Poetry and Graphic Novels to Read After The Hate U Give
posts.text: The film adaptation of Angie Thomas' novel is lending new energy to the award-winning, best-selling story about police violence and Black life in America. A lot of great lists online have already suggested dozens of fiction readalikes, so we thought we'd recommend books that address similar themes in a different format.

posts.title: Childhood Game-Changers: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 110
posts.text: When we asked our book experts about books that changed their lives, we fell in love with their picks — and we wanted you to hear what they had to say, in their own voices. Plus: Frank and Gwen add their own childhood game-changers.

posts.title: Wrapping Up Banned Books Week
posts.text: Libraries are committeed to providing the metaphorical mirrors, windows, and doors to a world outside readers' own experiences.

posts.title: When Escape Leads You Back to Reality: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 109
posts.text: Gwen and Frank discover two very different alternate worlds that speak to our present times. Their seemingly mismatched books offer stellar writing and clever takes on fantasy, dystopias and cringe-worthy identity politics. Plus: Frank has some, um... words for the author of his book.

posts.title: Thanks for Asking: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 108
posts.text: Rosa Caballero-Li, manager of Ask NYPL, has all the answers! Rosa tells Frank and Gwen about the ins, outs, ups, and downs of the Library's multifaceted reference service, staffed by real-live human people. Plus: a story within a story presents some guessing game twists.

posts.title: This Book Is No Joke: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 107
posts.text: Which books do you wish you'd read in high school? Frank and Gwen offer up some ideas and then move on to city novels with urban themes and a picture book about a dog who tries to be a fork. Plus: what to do if you can't get enough of the Queer Eye guys.

posts.title: 40 Books that Changed Librarians’ Lives
posts.text: In honor of the indubitable impact of J.K. Rowling’s work, we asked our book experts here at The New York Public Library to name a book that changed their lives, growing up. (And we asked them to choose books other than Harry Potter.)

posts.title: Harry Potter Meets Jane Eyre: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 106
posts.text: Gwen and Frank fall hard for the wise and wonderful Vanessa Zoltan of the Harry Potter and the Sacred Text podcast! We talk Harry and Jane, try the spiritual practice of lectio divina, discuss the healing power of romance novels, figure out Frank's Tinder profile... get ready for some serious revelations.

posts.title: Guess What SHOULDN'T Replace Libraries? The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 104
posts.text: Answer: anything! Frank and Gwen discuss why for-profit businesses cannot and should not take libraries' place in society. Plus, recommendations for two small books that contain very big worlds.

posts.title: Inspired by Crazy Rich Asians: 7 More Film-Worthy Books
posts.text: More books by Asian and Asian-American authors, and with memorable Asian and Asian-American characters, that we think would be big hits on the big screen.

posts.title: First Kisses, YA Romance, and Cameron Post
posts.text: These books tackle the most profound questions of life—love, loss, families, relationships, race, class, gender—and they cannot and should not be easily dismissed.

posts.title: America Is Not The Heart: The Librarian Is In, Ep. 103
posts.text: It's our third annual Summer Reading Challenge! This year, Frank and Gwen picked America Is Not the Heart, a debut novel by Elaine Castillo, about language and love and revolution and family and the meaning of home—it's about everything, and it's incredible.

posts.title: How Many Librarians Does It Take to Find a Forgotten Book?
posts.text: What do you get when you have 20 librarians in a room, furiously searching for answers? NYPL Title Quest.

posts.title: May I Remove Your Preconceived Notions? The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 102
posts.text: Frank and Gwen break down romance novel stereotypes with fellow NYPL librarian Anne Rouyer. The genre often gets dismissed as fluff, but romance can subvert the traditional confines of gender, power, class, and more. (Gay Regency, anyone?)

posts.title: What Makes a Good Beach Read? The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 101
posts.text: We're finding our midsummer vacation reading groove! Gwen is spectacularly awed by a debut novel and Frank gets drawn into a thriller (with a dash of reader real-estate jealousy).

posts.title: What's Your Literary Horoscope?
posts.text: Is today your lucky day? Should you go for that promotion? Who’s your true love match? We have no idea—but we do know books!

posts.title: 5 Kid Books That Are Just as Good as You Remember . . . Plus 5 Readalikes
posts.text: Some books are classics for a reason.

posts.title: Memory Lane: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 100
posts.text: We're 100 episodes old! Frank and Gwen mark their centennial by responding to listener messages and revisiting some favorite themes. Plus: a list of our favorite episodes for new (or new-ish) listeners.

posts.title: Read the Emmys!
posts.text: In this year's crop of nominees, several series and films have roots somewhere in the literary landscape. And as a viewer and a reader, you can gain a new perspective by finding the books that started it all and the supplemental reading materials that can take you deeper.

posts.title: On Your Mark, Get Set... The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 99
posts.text: It's time again for our Summer Reading Challenge! In this mini-episode, Frank and Gwen pick a book to dive into together and invite you to read along with them, so place those library holds for a copy of America Is Not the Heart by Elaine Castillo. Discussion to air August 9!

posts.title: WWGRRMR: What Would George R.R. Martin Read?
posts.text: Fans of George R.R. Martin—author of the Song of Ice and Fire series, among other hugely successful fantasy novels—have seen his imagined worlds brought to the screen in the popular HBO series, Game of Thrones. Martin's ideas have inspired readers to imagine dragons and queens, witches and conquerors, direwolves and White Walkers, dynasties and destinies.

posts.title: Border Stories: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 96
posts.text: Frank and Gwen share thoughts and reading recommendations about immigration, families, and children at the border. Plus: Frank asks what-if and Gwen ponders three recent books on motherhood.

posts.title: Crossing Food Boundaries: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 95
posts.text: Dr. Shayne Figueroa joins Frank and Gwen to discuss food nostalgia, Amish soul food (it's a thing!), and how NYC's free school lunch program is attempting to lift an age-old stigma. Plus: Frank's secret childhood eating habits and another guessing-game stumper.

posts.title: May I Remove Your Cravat? The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 94
posts.text: Frank and Gwen revisit the recent Booker Prize winner, Lincoln in the Bardo, as Frank gets serious about the afterlife and our understanding of history. Then Gwen turns the studio into a sauna with a gay Regency romance packed with period details and subplots that add depth to the steamy novel.

posts.title: Call Me, Jason Reynolds: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 93
posts.text: Gwen and Frank get a visit from Elisa Garcia, Supervising Librarian of Teen Services at the Bronx Library Center, who brings the guessing-game drama and recommendations galore. Plus: Elisa talks about moving to and growing up in the Bronx, the global influence of '90s hip-hop, and all around back-in-the-day coolness.

posts.title: If You Liked Fahrenheit 451, Try These...
posts.text: If you liked Fahrenheit 451 by Ray Bradbury, try more social-science fiction with a dash of bleak dystopia.

posts.title: If You Liked Olive Kitteridge, Try These...
posts.text: If you liked Olive Kitteridge by Elizabeth Strout, try more beautifully written, interconnected short stories.

posts.title: If You Liked The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks, Try These...
posts.text: For fans of The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks by Rebecca Skloot, try these compelling science titles.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: Unlikely YA Pairs
posts.text: Two books about zombies, two memoirs, and two books that might appeal to reluctant readers.

posts.title: If You Liked Show Me a Hero, Try These...
posts.text: If you liked Show Me a Hero: A Tale of Murder, Suicide, Race, and Redemption by Lisa Belkin, try other books that tell part of a city's history.

posts.title: If You Liked Angels in America, Try These...
posts.text: If you liked Angels in America by Tony Kushner, try more impassioned LGBTQ stories.

posts.title: Remembering Author Richard Peck
posts.text: Peck's deft touch and colorful characters, plus plenty of his trademark humor, endear his books to readers of all ages.

posts.title: It's Not You, Book, It's Me: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 92
posts.text: Frank confesses his sometimes-complicated relationship with certain books and his bouts of book insecurity. Plus: What happens when Frank and Gwen serendipitously read the same book around the same time but don't quite remember it the same way? And an unpublished work from the early 1930s finallly gets the recognition it deserves.

posts.title: Remembering Philip Roth
posts.text: Throughout his prolific career, he focused on intense characters, a blur between fiction and reality, and sweeping themes of religion, morality, male sexuality, and American identity.

posts.title: The Bronx Gets a New Book Festival: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 91
posts.text: Saraciea Fennell, founder of the Bronx Book Festival, joins Frank and Gwen to talk about bringing this event to the borough and the line-up for this weekend. Plus: how Saraciea found her way into the publishing world, zombies, Jane Austen, and a whole bunch of her favorite children's, YA, and fantasy reads.

posts.title: Remembering Tom Wolfe
posts.text: Wolfe’s legacy lives on at the New York Public Library; he was named a Library Lion in 1981 and the Library acquired his archives in 2013.

posts.title: Books for Moms: The Giving Tree and Beyond
posts.text: In honor of Mother's Day, the Library wants to salute books for kids that address the best things motherhood can stand for: love, generosity, a sense of safety in a tumultuous world... and, yes, giving.

posts.title: New & Noteworthy: New Fiction for Kids
posts.text: Our Best Books for Kids committee is hard at work, narrowing down the vast pool of new books. Here's some middle-grade fiction—targeted very generally toward kids around fifth through eighth grades—that's getting lots of buzz this month.

posts.title: Gwen's Book Flare: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 90
posts.text: What's the opposite of a book slump? We're calling it a flare, and Gwen is on one. She and Frank have a flurry of adult book recommendations, from dystopian novels to innovative science fiction.

posts.title: Singing in the Library: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 89
posts.text: What happens when you tap the musical talents of NYPL's librarians? Frank and Gwen get to relive their professional recording cameos with Sean Ferguson, manager of Chatham Square Library and a driving force behind the Library's new album for kids.

posts.title: Reading Across America: Young Readers' Edition
posts.text: Our NYPL book experts assembled 51 books—one for each state, plus the District of Columbia—for young readers, starting with bright picture books for the littlest kids and ending with evocative novels for young adults.

posts.title: Peyton DisPlaced: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 88
posts.text: Another crossover episode with our fine friends from the Overdue podcast! Frank and Gwen join Craig and Andrew in Philadelphia to discuss the 1956 novel Peyton Place.

posts.title: The Ultimate Avengers Guide
posts.text: We asked five of our NYPL book experts to come up with suggestions for every level of Avengers fan: where to start, the classics, the best of the newest stories, character-specific recommendations, and much more.

posts.title: These Books Show Why Earth Day Matters
posts.text: We’ve put together a list of nonfiction books published in the last few years that shed light on some of the biggest challenges to the planet’s ecosystem.

posts.title: The Great Work Continues: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 87
posts.text: Gwen & Frank's conversation with Dan Kois about " Angels in America" continues. Plus: NYPL Curator Doug Reside shares items from the Library of the Performing Arts!

posts.title: The Great Work Begins: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 86
posts.text: Author Dan Kois discusses his recent book, "The World Only Spins Forward: The Ascent of Angels in America," a collection of oral histories from nearly 250 people about Tony Kushner's iconic play.

posts.title: Kidlit: In Praise of the Humble Puddle
posts.text: Spring is finally here, and with it comes every kid's springtime best friend: the puddle.

posts.title: Feline Good with Our Favorite Literary Cats
posts.text: In the spirit of feline companionship, we asked our NYPL book experts: Which books star your favorite literary cats?

posts.title: Hard-boiled Noir: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 85
posts.text: Frank dives into the dark and depraved world of noir, explains the basics of the genre, and delivers a saucy read from one of his favorite books. Gwen does some detective work herself, taking us on her journey of a book rec that takes a dark turn of its own! Plus: radio drama, man tears, and some classic YA literature.

posts.title: Visiting the City of Librarianly Love: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 84
posts.text: Frank and Gwen headed to Philadelphia and brought home the sights, sounds, and book recommendations of the Public Library Association's 2018 conference. Plus, hard-hitting journalism: Is breakfast the most important meal of a librarian's day?

posts.title: Bedtime Stories: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 83
posts.text: Gwen and Frank share books recs for bedtime—good reads for kids of all ages, and one that's definitely for grown-ups only. Plus, if you're at the Public Library Association conference in Philadelphia (March 22-23), come find Frank and Gwen for even more talk about reading recs, pick up some podcast swag, and share what books are stacked on your bedside table!

posts.title: Yup, Reading Makes Us Happy
posts.text: We asked the bookworms of Twitter to name the stories that bring them happiness. After all, everyone knows that reading improves your health, sharpens your mind, helps you embrace ambiguity, and makes you more empathetic—but let's not forget that most of us just do it because we love it.

posts.title: #LibraryLife in Literature
posts.text: Inspired (sort of) by Neil’s journey in Goodbye Columbus, we asked our book experts for recommendations of other books with main characters who work in libraries or archives.

posts.title: Spring into New Staff Picks!
posts.text: Yeah, we went with the dorky season pun! That's just how excited we are about our newest round of Staff Picks—more than 100 titles that our NYPL book experts are super-excited about reading right now.

posts.title: Small (Town Library) Talk: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 82
posts.text: Frank and Gwen chat with Steven Kurutz, a New York Times features reporter, about his recent Literary Hub essay, "In Praise of the Small Town Library." It's part coming-of-age story, part love letter to his hometown library in Renovo, Pennsylvania. Plus: book rituals, a wild non-book recommendation, and the enduring charm of an unconventional librarian.

posts.title: A Wrinkle in Time Read-a-Likes
posts.text: If you liked A Wrinkle in Time, try a few more children's books with bold protagonists, exciting adventures, and a touch of the fantastical.

posts.title: The LibROCKian Is In: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 81
posts.text: Fred and Barney... er, Frank and Gwen are reading books with different approaches to the same question: Who are you and what do you want out of life? (This episode has nothing to do with The Flintstones after the first 30 seconds, but the puns cannot be denied.)

posts.title: The Bernstein Awards 2018: Meet the Finalists
posts.text: Every year, The New York Public Library honors a journalist with the Helen Bernstein Book Award for Excellence in Journalism. This year’s books address insider trading, the threatened Great Lakes, and the Trump presidency, as well as the current state of affairs in Russia.

posts.title: Living in the Library: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 80
posts.text: Actor Sharon Washington joins us to talk about her one-woman play "Feeding the Dragon," based on her experience growing up inside a New York Public Library branch in the 1970s. She tells us about her childhood in the library after hours, and what it's like to share her story on stage. Plus: horror movie recs and getting judgy on Law and Order.

posts.title: The 2018 Oscars: Watch That? Read This.
posts.text: We have nearly all of the films available to check out of the Library. But don't stop there: We've also picked out a few books that have similar themes or resonate particularly well with this year's nominees.

posts.title: The First Rule of Diverse Books Club Is... The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 79
posts.text: RuthAnn Deveney from the Diverse Books Club gives us a behind-the-scenes look at her group's themes and book picks, her love of spreadsheets, and her Philly-specific sandwich recommendations. Plus: What will Frank say (or not say) when he goes on The View?

posts.title: Book Pairings for the Winter Olympics
posts.text: Books to read while you're relaxing on the couch, watching world-class athletes compete in the Olympics.

posts.title: A Black Panther Primer
posts.text: We’re obsessed with Black Panther. So, we’ve come up with some book selections for every kind of Black Panther fan, from the movie-goers who’ve never read the comics to the long-time completists.

posts.title: New Yaaawk Stories: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 78
posts.text: All the complexities of the city so nice, they named it twice! Frank goes deep into nostalgia territory, digging up childhood memories, classic accents, and urban anxieties. Gwen follows with a real-life tale of greed and gumption at a famed NYC hedge fund.

posts.title: Never Too Old to Blume: A Celebration of Judy Blume
posts.text: Judy Blume’s work for children and teens has a timeless quality, and her work for adults is groundbreaking as well. If you’ve never read her work for adults, here are three novels you should read.

posts.title: 2018 Winners: Newbery, Caldecott, King, Printz & More
posts.text: It was a big morning in literature for young people: The American Library Association announced the winners of their prestigiousYouth Media Awards at the Midwinter meeting in Atlanta.

posts.title: Slow-Burn Reads for a Lightning-Fast News Cycle
Don't Shush Me! The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 76
posts.text: It's World Read Aloud Day, and Gwen and Frank are hearing voices... from ghosts and robots. But they still manage to keep it together to recommend some books and play an extra round of their guessing game.

posts.title: #ReadingBlackout: 28 Days of Books By and About African Americans for Black History Month
posts.text: It's Black History Month, and we've selected one book by and/or about African Americans to recommend for each day of February.

posts.title: Ursula K. Le Guin for the Young and Old (and In Between)
posts.text: Thinking about Le Guin’s legacy, we wanted to highlight not the science fiction and fantasy that she’s famous for, but her other work — her memoir and essays, which capture her honesty and wit, and her children’s books, which many people may not have known existed.

posts.title: NYPL’s Most-Anticipated YA Books of 2018
posts.text: Our young-adult specialists are eagerly anticipating a flurry of upcoming releases this year! Check out the books and graphic novels that have them the most fired up.

posts.title: The Witches of YA
posts.text: YA fiction has long held a special place in its collective heart for brujas, mages, and would-be spell-casters from Salem and far beyond.

posts.title: Survey Says... The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 74
posts.text: IS Margaret Atwood a bad feminist? Yeeeeeesh, we don't know. Frank and Gwen talk about the allegations against Aziz Ansari and then, thankfully, move onto books: nonfiction about young immigrants from El Salvador and a novel about a sci-fi dating experiment. Also, help us out by taking our survey at nypl.org/podcastsurvey!

posts.title: The Haberdashery of Kid Lit
posts.text: Where would some of our favorite literary kiddos be if not for their fabulous headwear? And what better time to celebrate them than National Hat Day?

posts.title: Start Your Reading Year with New Staff Picks
posts.text: Ready to expand your reading horizons in 2018? Embrace the challenge with our newest round of Staff Picks!

posts.title: Reading the 2018 Golden Globes
posts.text: Novels, biographies, works of fantasy and science fiction, and other books played big roles in the films and television honored at the 75th Golden Globe Awards.

posts.title: New Year, New (Reading) You: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 72
posts.text: Want to broaden reading your horizons this year? Librarian extraordinaire Meredith Mann joins Frank and Gwen to debate the pros and cons of annual reading challenges. Plus: secret database magic, sci-fi written by robots, and our favorite British bakers.

posts.title: Read Harder in 2018! NYPL's Suggestions for Book Riot’s Annual Challenge
posts.text: If you're taking on Book Riot's Read Harder Challenge, we’re here for you. Below are suggestions in each category for books in the New York Public Library’s collections. You could even add an extra facet to this challenge: Complete it using only books you checked out from your local library!

posts.title: Seven Picture Books for Kwanzaa
posts.text: Kwanzaa brings many African-American families together to enjoy the "first fruits of the harvest," the Swahili phrase from which its name is derived. Its traditions, like lighting the seven candles on the kinara and feasting at a party on the last night of the holiday, center around family and community.

posts.title: Nine New Christmas Classics for Kids
posts.text: Nothing can ever replace Frosty or the Grinch, or that mouse that isn't stirring. But plenty of talented authors and illustrators have been hard at work creating new characters and stories, so we've picked out a few new Christmas picture books published in the last few years for your holiday consideration.

posts.title: That Episode about 'Cat Person': The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 70
posts.text: Gwen and Frank take on "Cat Person," the New Yorker story that turned the Internet upside down, and make some book recs based on its tone and subject.

posts.title: Back to the Burrow: Holidays with Our Favorite Fictional Families
posts.text: Until Mrs. Weasley knits you a sweater with your initial on it, here are a few ideas for ideal families to spend the holidays with.

posts.title: Kids' Books To Celebrate Both Hanukkah & Christmas
posts.text: Families who celebrate both Christmas and Hanukkah might find something that hits home in these picture books about interfaith families, combining different kinds of traditions, and, yes, sentient potato pancakes.

posts.title: Masha Gessen: Where to Begin
posts.text: This post is part of a series in which Readers Services librarians suggest a good starting place for authors appearing in our LIVE from the NYPL series.

posts.title: Looking for Peak Coziness? Look No Further.
posts.text: It’s a cold and rainy day in New York, and we’re here to answer the burning question on everyone’s mind: How can I achieve peak coziness today?

posts.title: Cozy Chanukah Picture Books
posts.text: Many readers might know a few old standbys, but more recently published books about the Festival of Lights go beyond the standard dreidel-based fare. We have stories about Yiddish-speaking chickens, Braille dreidels, immigrants stranded at sea, families who fry up dosas instead of latkes, and more.

posts.title: The 12 Days of Bookness
posts.text: No matter what you celebrate during this time of year, the time is right for curling up with a special beverage of your choice and a really great new book. We've compiled a list of suggestions, hand-selected by our Readers Services team, to brighten your December. Check back every day until December 22 for a new category.

posts.title: Where Are the Fat-Positive Children's Books? The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 68
posts.text: Spoiler alert: They barely exist! Frank and Gwen talk to librarian and advocate Angie Manfredi about the missing fat kids (and adults) in literature, the importance of body diversity in books, and the danger of creating a monolith of marginalized voices.

posts.title: Naomi Klein: Where to Begin
posts.text: This post is part of a series in which Readers Services librarians suggest a good starting place for authors appearing in our LIVE from the NYPL series.

posts.title: This Episode Was Really Hard To Title: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 67
posts.text: Gwen goes nuts for an alt-history about hippo ranching (IT COULD HAVE BEEN A REAL THING!), and Frank goes nuts for a memoir by an incomparable actor and role model Gabourey Sidibe.

posts.title: Finding a Book When You've Forgotten Its Title
posts.text: It can be tough to remember the title of a book you read a long time ago—even if it was really important to you. Librarians have a few tricks to help you find what you're looking for.

posts.title: A Thanksgiving Best Books Grace-Off! The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 66
posts.text: Settle in with your turducken and check out our 2017 Best Books for Kids and Teens! Take a deep dive into NYPL's annual lists, with committee members Grace Yamada and Grace Dwyer debating their favorites and recommending titles.

posts.title: Best Books for Kids 2017: 100 Titles for Reading and Sharing
posts.text: This list is a century-old tradition in which the New York Public Library’s librarians and other book experts select 100 noteworthy children's titles from several categories: picture books, young readers, middle-grade fiction, graphic novels, folklore & fairy tales, poetry, and nonfiction.

posts.title: Introducing the Best Books for Teens 2017
posts.text: A committee of 20 dedicated librarians read (and read and read) all the young-adult books published in 2016 that we could get our hands on. Then we debated, voted, and came up with our 50 favorite books of the year—fiction, nonfiction, graphic novels, comic books, fantasy, history, romance, sports, and more.

posts.title: Meet the 2017 National Book Award Finalists (and Winners!)
posts.text: The literati are eagerly anticipating this year's National Book Award winners, who will be announced on Wednesday, Nov. 15, around 7:20 p.m.

posts.title: Children’s Book Characters We Wish Were Friends
posts.text: In honor of the fast friends Lindgren created, we asked our book experts here at the New York Public Library to name their ideal friend pairings—characters we’d love to see together, irrespective of time, place, or genre.

posts.title: Happy Robert Louis Stevenson Day!
posts.text: Every year on November 13, the city of Edinburgh goes all-out for the birthday of a hometown hero: author Robert Louis Stevenson.

posts.title: Frank Brings the Creepy: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 64
posts.text: This week on TLII, Frank has a creepy middle-grade/YA novel that's great for adults, and Gwen has a not-at-all-creepy chapter book for preschoolers and early readers that's sure to also delight parents.

posts.title: How to Pull Yourself Out of a Book Slump: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 63
posts.text: Gwen and Frank are both struggling to find the perfect book this week — and coming up with some ideas about how to do it. Plus: the glory that is Ilana Glazer.

posts.title: Readers Respond: What Book Can't You Finish?
posts.text: Previously, we asked our librarians what books they've never been able to finish--yes, even librarians have books we just can't finish.

posts.title: Hey, Mr. Producer: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 61
posts.text: Against his better judgment, the producer of "The Librarian Is In" joins Gwen and Frank to talk books, tattoos, and how the podcast came to be.

posts.title: The Unexpected Catalog of George Saunders
posts.text: George Saunders just won the Man Booker Prize for his 2017 novel, Lincoln in the Bardo, which was (amazingly) his very first novel-length work of fiction.

posts.title: John Green Readalikes All the Way Down
posts.text: Waiting for Turtles All the Way Down? You're not alone. So put your name on the holds list and then check out some of our favorite John Green readalikes — character-driven, emotional, engaging reads about teen relationships —  to check out while you wait.

posts.title: Kazuo Ishiguro: Where to Begin
posts.text: Kazuo Ishiguro, consummate British novelist and 2014 Library Lion, won the Nobel Prize in Literature today. His work is varied, complicated, and fascinating — and these three books are a good place to start.

posts.title: Cat Books for the Youngest Readers
posts.text: Seven picture books for the young feline fanatics out there.

posts.title: Heaven Is a Place on... Another Planet? The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 58
posts.text: Frank and Gwen traverse the globe and beyond this week, with two dystopian YA books about life on other planets and a memoir about international travel, journalism, and feminism. Plus: Banned Books Week and, yes, Belinda Carlisle.

posts.title: Top 5 Most-Challenged Books of 2016 Include LGBTQ Themes
posts.text: When the American Library Association (ALA) recently published its annual list of the most frequently challenged books in the nation, we noticed something similar about the top five most-challenged books: All of them feature LGBTQ characters and storylines.

posts.title: Llama-Famous! Poetry Extravaganza: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 57
posts.text: Podcasts are red/Podcasts are blue/This episode's all poetry/We hope you like it too!

posts.title: Quiz: Whodunnit? Marple vs. Poirot
posts.text: In honor of Christie’s birthday on Sept. 15, 1890, we created a quiz to see if you can tell her two most memorable creations apart.

posts.title: The Great Nancy Pearl! The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 55
posts.text: Frank and Gwen are beyond thrilled to talk to Nancy Pearl, a.k.a. America's Librarian, a.k.a. the guru of readers' advisory, a.k.a. OUR HERO. We talk about her new novel, George & Lizzie, and the perils of and triumphs of writing fiction. Plus: We guess Nancy's mystery book on the very first try...

posts.title: Books for Kids' Back-to-School Jitters
posts.text: Six stories that might help ease the minds of kids feeling anxious about their first days of school.

posts.title: The Biggest Fish in the Sea
posts.text: What’s your favorite book in which a character chases a seemingly unattainable goal? (And do they achieve it?)

posts.title: Our Favorite Literary Wafflers
posts.text: We asked our NYPL book experts to come up with characters who make readers suffer along with their agonizing indecision — in other words, the best literary wafflers!

posts.title: NYPL Recommends: New YA Fiction, Dog Days Edition
posts.text: Romance, relationships, action, adventure, Korean dramas, letters to Mars... what more could a YA fan ask for?

posts.title: Charlottesville in Context: A Reading List
posts.text: Events of the past week have left many of us struggling for understanding. In such times, it can help to turn to books and authors to help us see the world through a broader lens.

posts.title: The Right Book at the Right Time: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 52
posts.text: Frank and Gwen tackle two powerful narratives of self-acceptance -- and then take respite in a roller derby comic and a love story.

posts.title: Celebrating New Arab-American Literature
posts.text: Satan and Death presiding over the waiting room of a psychiatric clinic, a sailboat and a map to pirate’s treasure, the loss of a beloved cat… the subjects of the books that won this year’s Arab American Book Awards  are as diverse as they are creative.

posts.title: Only Love Will Save the World: Wonder Woman Readalikes
posts.text: With nearly $800 million in revenue and counting, Wonder Woman is smashing box-office records and lighting imaginations on fire. And books are smoldering, too!

posts.title: Books That Talk and Books You Touch: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 50
posts.text: Frank and Gwen  learn about the Library's work with patrons with print disabilities with Jill Rothstein, chief librarian at the Andrew Heiskell Braille & Talking Book Library. Plus: More book recommendations than we've ever crammed into any episode, probably ever.

posts.title: Children's Books about Death, Loss, and Grieving
posts.text: Many children must face the terminal illness and death of pets, grandparents, other friends and family members, and more. Even children who aren’t directly dealing with loss or grieving often still have questions about the concepts.

posts.title: NYPL Recommends: New YA for July
posts.text: No such thing as summer vacation for great new YA fiction, nonfiction, comics, and graphic novels! Here are the titles for teens that we're most excited about putting on our shelves.

posts.title: What Kind of Beach Read Do You Need?
posts.text: "Beach read" could mean something different to everyone — so we've come up with some categories of recommendations that will help you figure out what kind of beach book you're looking for.

posts.title: Summer Reading Challenge, Greeks vs. Romans: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 48
posts.text: For our second Summer Reading Challenge, Gwen and Frank chose a book for each other that they thought they'd love but would never read otherwise. This year, a strange symmetry emerged as they chose oddly complementary books: a novel about the antics of ancient Greek students and a modern-day translation of ancient Roman myths.

posts.title: Celebrating the Better Halves: Our Favorite Literary Sidekicks
posts.text: As a birthday gift for the long-suffering, under-appreciated Dr. Watson — who usually narrates the stories himself — we asked our book experts to name literature’s best sidekicks.

posts.title: Scandal! The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 47
posts.text: Who's up for some dubious morality? We're all about the scandal this week, as Frank and Gwen tackle controversial essays, what makes a "beach read," and, um, porcupines in library book drops.

posts.title: Nancy Books: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 46
posts.text: The hosts of WNYC's Nancy podcast join Gwen and Frank for a conversation about queer books, making podcasts, and Xena Warrior Princess... while they were on vacation, no less! Kathy and Tobin—BFFs who are super queer and super fun, according to their Official Podcast Description—called in from California to talk about their favorite reads past and present and the stories they can't wait to tell.

posts.title: #SubwayLibrary Suggestions: Short Reads
posts.text: There's so much available to read on the #SubwayLibrary, it can be hard to choose which books to peruse on your commute.  This week's category: short reads! You can read any of these short stories, essays, and other short pieces in just one or two subway trips.

posts.title: #ReadersUnite: Our Summer Reading Challenge for Adults
posts.text: Summer means one thing to librarians: summer reading.

posts.title: #SubwayLibrary Suggestions: Books for Young Adults
posts.text: There's so much available to read on the #SubwayLibrary—a service that delivers free e-books brought to you by MTA, Transit Wireless, and NYC's libraries—it can be hard to choose which books to peruse on your commute.

posts.title: Seeing Yourself on the Page: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 44
posts.text: The fantastic Sona Charaipotra sits down with Frank and Gwen to talk representation and what it's like to see (or not see) your own experiences reflected in a book. Plus: Archie and Riverdale, Bollywood, Hollywood, and a lot of geeking out over our favorite YA authors.

posts.title: Steamy Summer Staff Picks
posts.text: It's heating up outside, and our summer Staff Picks have arrived just in time for those long-awaited beach trips (or sweltering subway rides, when you really need an escape).

posts.title: NYPL Recommends: New Poetry for Kids
posts.text: Poetry is perfect for the youngest readers—great for developing vocabularies and fun for adults to read out loud. Check out some newly published books, all of which can be found in the Library's nonfiction section.

posts.title: Sherlock vs. Sayers: Who Said It?
posts.text: We've put a master of detective stories up against a master of detectives. Even though the words were written more than a century apart, Sayers and Sherlock share a similar sensibility and a wicked sense of humor.

posts.title: NYPL Recommends: New YA for June
posts.text: A cappella, interstellar journeys, high-stakes card games in Sin City, and the Van Gogh brothers? Don't mind if we do! Check out some of our NYPL book experts' newest favorites.

posts.title: Announcing #SubwayLibrary: Free E-Books for Your Commute
posts.text: We're excited to announce the launch of Subway Library, a new initiative between The New York Public Library, Brooklyn Public Library, and Queens Library, the MTA, and Transit Wireless that provides subway riders in New York City with free access to hundreds of e-books, excerpts, and short stories—all ready to read on the train.

posts.title: #RainbowReading for Teens: 30 Books for 30 Days of Pride Month 2017
posts.text: We’re excited to present our favorite LGBTQ+ books each day of June -- and the books on this list are some of our favorites about and for LGBTQ+ teens.

posts.title: #RainbowReading for Adults: 30 Books for 30 Days of Pride Month 2017
posts.text: June is Pride month, of course, but it’s also GLBT Book Month! We’re excited to present our favorite LGBTQ+ books each day of June.

posts.title: #RainbowReading for Kids: 30 Books for 30 Days of Pride Month 2017
posts.text: June isn't just Pride Month, it's also GLBT Book Month -- which means we have an opportunity to talk about some of the coolest, sweetest, most innovative books for kids: literature by, for, and about LGBTQ+ families.

posts.title: Go West, Fair Readers
posts.text: What makes a “modern Western”? In honor of Larry McMurtry’s birthday, we asked our book experts here at the New York Public Library to answer that question — and to name a book they’d recommend that fit into that category.

posts.title: Dark, Light, & In Between: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 41
posts.text: We're swinging from heavy, major, important nonfiction to the frothiest and most delightful YA romance this week. Plus: Frank and Gwen make the producer thankful for his upcoming vacation.

posts.title: NYPL Recommends: New YA for May
posts.text: Great reads for young adults are blossoming like crazy this spring. Check out some of the reads — fiction, nonfiction, and graphic novels — that our YA librarians are buzzing about.

posts.title: Making Grown Men Cry, Since 2015: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 39
posts.text: Sweet-sad poems, ghosts of the Village Past, and melancholy post-Victorian tales of ruined childhoods in creeepy cults... But we manage to have a little fun, too.

posts.title: I Won’t Grow Up! Adult Books Featuring the Stubbornly Young
posts.text: In honor of J.M. Barrie's most famous creation — Peter Pan, the eternally young boy forever living in Neverland — we asked our book experts at The New York Public Library for recommendations of books that have Peter-like characters who simply refuse to grow up.

posts.title: Serving the Least Served: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 38
posts.text: This week, we talk libraries and activism with Cory Eckert, one of the joint chiefs of Storytime Underground! We go in-depth on libraries as non-neutral spaces and how children's librarians stand up for social justice. Plus: recommendations for romance novels and two brand-new picture books.

posts.title: Every Day Is Free Comic Book Day at the Library
posts.text: A primer on comics and graphic novels! Expand your horizons, and visit your library AND your indie comic shop.

posts.title: Books about the Best of Times, Books about the Worst of Times
posts.text: We asked our book experts to pick a side: what are some of your favorite books that feature a character having the best of times OR the worst of times?

posts.title: "Hermione Was Black. Dumbledore Was Gay." The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 36
posts.text: We kick off our weekly podcast adventure with the founders of Black Girls Create! We talk about what it's like to be a black girl nerd, defaulting to whiteness in books and pop culture, nerds vs. geeks vs. dweebs, feminism and visibility and representation -- and, of course, sooooo much Harry Potter.

posts.title: Love ‘The Handmaid’s Tale’? Try One of These.
posts.text: Whether you’re waiting for your copy from the library or you’ve already read the Atwood classic and are looking for a good follow-up, we have a few suggestions.

posts.title: NYPL Recommends: New YA Nonfiction, April Showers Edition
posts.text: The great new young-adult titles just keep coming this spring! Check out five exciting true stories for young adults, all published in the last few months.

posts.title: Our Favorite Fictional Librarians, Ranked
posts.text: Pop culture isn't always kind to librarians. So, in honor of National Library Week, we thought we'd pick half a dozen of our favorite library workers—good and evil and in between—and give them some fictional performance evaluations, complete with numerical rankings.

posts.title: Podcasting the Apocalypse: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 35
posts.text: We’re going weekly!  One week, Gwen and Frank will talk books, culture, and what to read next. On alternate weeks they’ll welcome a very special guest. Let us know what you think of this new format!

posts.title: Long Books That Are Worth It, We Promise
posts.text: We asked our book experts to recommend their favorite long books—the ones that are really, truly worth the time it takes to read them.

posts.title: Spring Staff Picks Ahoy!
posts.text: Here at The New York Public Library, our book experts have outdone themselves with the newest round of

posts.title: What Lawyers and Librarians Have in Common: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 34
posts.text: Reena Glazer of the Pro Bono Institute joins Frank and Gwen to talk about lawyers in the library and recommendations for great nonfiction about pro bono legal work. Plus: Purple diaries, yellow cable cars, and colorful characters.

posts.title: Supermodel of the World:  Sashay, Shauntee!  The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 33
posts.text: Wait, Super Model? Absolutely, but also: Super Librarian!  Gwen and Frank talk to Outreach Services Librarian Shauntee Burns about her work with schools, her long and varied career at NYPL and her attendance at one very famous NYC high school!

posts.title: Remembering Amy Krouse Rosenthal, Master of Wordplay
posts.text: On the cover of Amy Krouse Rosenthal’s unconventional 2005 memoir, four sentences are written above the title: “I have not survived against all odds. I have not lived to tell. I have not witnessed the extraordinary. This is my story.”

posts.title: From Snowy Days to Scientists: Books Featuring Kids and Families of Color
posts.text: Ezra Jack Keats' The Snowy Day , first published in March 1962, follows a little boy exulting in a big snowfall in New York City. In the tradition of Keats' classic, we asked our NYPL experts to recommend children’s books that feature kids and families of color.

posts.title: 365 Books by Women Authors to Celebrate International Women’s Day All Year
posts.text: For over a century, International Women's Day has been observed on March 8--and we've compiled 365 books by women authors from across the globe to keep the celebration going all year long.

posts.title: 16 Books about Refugees for Kids & Adults
posts.text: World Refugee Day is June 20, and these stories of refugee experiences are important reads throughout the year. Listed by age group, these books—including many first-person accounts, written by refugees—are a great place to start.

posts.title: A Librarian’s Path to Citizenship: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 32
posts.text: How do libraries help immigrants and underserved communities? Find out with NYPL's very own Adriana Blancarte-Hayward. Plus: major love for great journalism, time travel, ghosts, Frank's hair, frozen yogurt, and Salt 'n Pepa.

posts.title: Best Nonfiction of the Year: Announcing The 30th Annual Helen Bernstein Book Award Finalists
posts.text: The Bernstein Award honors working journalists whose books bring clarity and public attention to important issues, events, or policies. This year's finalists' works cover Syria, plutocrats, refugee crises, the spread of contagious disease, and gun violence in America.

posts.title: Kilts, Cupcakes, and Romance Novels: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 31
posts.text: Frank and Gwen dive into two very different romance novels with NYPL librarians Annie Lin and Kate Fais.  Plus: a super-clean podcast, a binge-watch-able show, and a gender-bending picture book.

posts.title: Black Scientists Who Changed the World
posts.text: In honor of Black History Month — and riding high on the box office success of Hidden Figures — we wanted to learn more about the lives of black scientists, many of whom were long overlooked by historians.

posts.title: Waiting for a Copy of 1984? Try One of These.
posts.text: Orwell's classic isn't the only dystopian game in town. While you're waiting, check out some of these other serious, thought-provoking novels on our shelves—physical and virtual—right now.

posts.title: At Home and Abroad: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 30
posts.text: With books on the Syrian refugee crisis and American "hillbilly" culture, Frank and Gwen are looking for a deeper undstanding of the world here at home, and abroad. Also, dinosaurs. And then, the inimitable Nancy Aravecz, NYPL trainee and library-school student, joins us to talk about the core principles of libraries and the equal-opportunity learning at Jefferson Market University.

posts.title: Words That Readers Can’t Say
posts.text: English is a difficult and capricious (kah-PRI-shuss) language, and we’ve compiled a huge list of words that our NYPL book experts mispronounced as kids — or still do! — because they’d only seen them in print.

posts.title: Wonderful Winter Staff Picks
Newbery Winners We Love
posts.text: Every January, the American Library Association’s Midwinter conference makes headlines with its announcement of the newest Newbery Medal and Honor winners. The coveted awards, which mark the best children’s books of the year, began in 1922.

posts.title: Lord of the Guys: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 29
posts.text: Frank and Gwen welcome Andrew and Craig of the Overdue podcast for a deep dive into William Golding's 1954 classic, Lord of the Flies. Every reader for him/her/reallyjustHIMself...

posts.title: Cheesy Books for Literary Cheese-Lovers
posts.text: In honor of National Cheese Lover’s Day, we asked our book experts to recommend their favorite cheesy books — romance of all stripes, coming-of-age stories, sappy cozy mysteries, anything they wanted — and tell us their favorite kinds of actual cheese, too.

posts.title: #ReadersUnite! The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 28
posts.text: Happy new year! Christopher Platt joins Gwen and Frank to talk about hate crimes, privacy and transparency, and how to start a revolution from your local library. Plus: Project Gutenberg reads, our technological future, and our crush on Carla Hayden.

posts.title: NYPL’s Most Recommended Books of 2016
posts.text: We tailor each recommendation to each patron's personal preferences, but there are some books that come up over and over again... either because they're stellar examples of a genre, because they check so many boxes for qualities people are looking for, or because they're books we read and loved ourselves this year.

posts.title: Miss Havisham, Try Tinder! And Other Literary New Year’s Resolutions
posts.text: ​'Tis the season for self-improvement, and we're thinking about the health and well-being of our favorite literary characters.

posts.title: Remembering Carrie Fisher, the Author
posts.text: Let’s begin by remembering Carrie Fisher the way she wanted to be remembered.

posts.title: Your 2017 Reading Calendar: Round Out Your Reading This Year
posts.text: With our 2017 reading calendars, you can focus your reading on something new and emerge at the end of 2017 a more well-rounded reader.

posts.title: Five Tales of Chanukah Romance
posts.text: Christmas love stories are huge, and Chanukah is getting in on the action. All the same great tropes apply: cold hands, warm hearts, candlelight, strolls down snowy streets, cozy snuggles in front of the fire... you know the drill.

posts.title: Taking On the 2017 Read Harder Challenge? Start Here.
posts.text: At the start of each new year, our friends at Book Riot issue a challenge: Read consciously, thoughtfully, and outside your comfort zone.

posts.title: So Long, 2016: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 27
posts.text: Welcome to our Very Special Holiday Mini-Episode! We talk about our families' book-giving traditions, Santa stress, and a few random gift suggestions.

posts.title: Children’s Books, Inclusivity, and Why It Matters
posts.text: We need to see empathy in action, and picture books are the right place to start.

posts.title: Honoring Grace Paley: Fiction, Activism, & Social Justice
posts.text: In honor of Grace Paley’s birthday, we asked our book experts to name fiction writers whose political action informed their work — not just indirectly advocated for a particular viewpoint, but whose activism was demonstrated in the stories they created.

posts.title: Lots of Good Fun That Is Funny: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 26
posts.text: Children's librarian Louise Lareau joins Frank and Gwen to talk about NYPL's annual Best Books for Kids list and why you should say "underpants" during first-grade storytime. Plus: Eve Babitz, Joan Didion, Zadie Smith, joy, suffering, existentialism, etc., etc.

posts.title: Introducing the Best Books for Teens 2016
posts.text: A committee of 20 dedicated librarians read all the young-adult books published in 2016 that we could get our hands on. Then we debated, voted, and came up with our 50 favorite books of the year.

posts.title: Librarians' Favorite Twain Quotations
posts.text: In honor of Twain’s birthday, we asked our experts here at The New York Public Library to recommend not only their favorite books by the Missouri author, but their favorite quotations as well.

posts.title: Turkeys Strike Back: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 25
posts.text: Gwen and Frank are joined by Sarah Ball from NYPL's Correctional Services unit to talk about library services for people in jail or prison. Plus: what we're reading, books we're thankful for, and a whole lot of Frank's singing.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: November 27, 2016
posts.text: Suspense—historical, noir, legal, and more—is the name of the game this week, with two new nailbiters on the list.

posts.title: Celebrate the Best Books for Teens 2016!
posts.text: We're throwing not one, not two, but THREE parties — one at Bronx Library Center, one at Hamilton Grange Library, and one at Stapleton Library —  on Thursday, Dec. 1, at 4 PM, to celebrate the release of our Best Books for Teens list.

posts.title: NYPL Recommends: Tales of the Marooned
posts.text: It’s a classic plot device: What do people do when they’re stranded? What happens to society when our connections  dissolve and individuals have to function on their own?

posts.title: NYPL Favorites for Comic Con
posts.text: Nerds of all stripes are gearing up for New York Comic Con, which begins Oct. 6 and runs through the weekend. Many of us at NYPL are especially excited, because the first day of the conference focuses on comic books, graphic novels, and manga.

posts.text: Pirates and sheriffs make their way onto the bestseller list this week, with three newcomers in the top five.

posts.title: Brainy and Brave: A Salute to Hermione Granger
posts.text: There can only ever be one Hermione, but these other brainy, brave heroines from young-adult and middle-grade fiction remind us of her in some important ways.

posts.title: Winnie-the-Podcast: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 21
posts.text: Eeyore, Tigger, Kanga, and Roo join Frank and Gwen in the studio this week... just kidding. But we have the next best thing: Michael Inman, curator of NYPL's Rare Book Division, who tells us about the restoration of the Library's historic Winnie-the-Pooh dolls. Plus: children's and YA books galore, and queens of all kinds.

posts.title: Want to Read More Diverse Books? Start Here.
posts.text: A shortcut to finding more books by authors of color.

posts.title: 'Read with a Child': Remembering Anna Dewdney

posts.title: The Ultimate Gilmore Girls Reading List
posts.text: Here's a list of books that I'd recommend to the citizens of Stars Hollow if I were behind the reference desk at the SHPL.
