posts.title: (Literary) Disco Dancing: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 20
posts.text: Frank and Gwen are joined by Julia Pistell, co-host of the Literary Disco podcast! We play multiple rounds of guess-the-book, talk about whaling ships and virtual reality and Garfield Minus Garfield, and offer a bazillion book recommendations.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: September 4, 2016
posts.text: Readers just can't get enough of the girl on that train, as Paula Hawkins' thriller once again ascends to the No. 1 spot. Plus: new stories of suspense, historical fiction, and more.

posts.title: 6 Books for Kids about the Civil Rights Movement
posts.text: Half a century after the Montgomery Bus Boycott that began with Rosa Parks, many authors of children’s literature are writing compelling middle-grade stories about the Civil Rights Movement in the 1950s and ’60s.

posts.title: A Labyrinth of Labyrinth Books
posts.text: In honor of Borges’ spirit of ingenuity (and his August birthday), we created a flowchart of books about twisty mazes, both real and imagined.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: August 28, 2016
posts.text: Two new titles join this list this week: historical fiction about the Underground Railroad and the newest installment of a popular series of F.B.I. thrillers.

posts.title: Hot Garbage, Summer in the City: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 19
posts.text: Humidity can't exist in outer space! Beat the heat by blasting off into orbit with Frank and Gwen's brand-new segment. Plus: Do audiobooks "count" as reading?

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: August 21, 2016
posts.text: Cozy small towns, private investigators, girls on trains... this week's list has a bit of everything, including a new J Patt thriller debuting in the No. 1 spot.

posts.title: Hitchcock-ian Reads
posts.text: It's the birthday of Alfred Hitchcock. To honor the Master of Suspense, our crackerjack team of book experts came up with a list of books that would do him proud: psychological suspense novels that give readers the same creepy, think-y thrill as watching his movies... and feature twists that no one saw coming.

posts.title: 16 Harry Potter Readalikes... Because The Cursed Child Is Not Enough
posts.text: It’s almost impossible to recreate the kind of world-building that J. K. Rowling achieved in her legendary Harry Potter series—which is why Harry Potter readalikes are the holy grail of book recommendations.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: August 15, 2016
posts.text: Lots of love in the air this week, with a new family drama in the No. 1 spot and a new paranormal romance at No. 4.

posts.title: Frankster and The Veve: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 18
posts.text: Up for some agony? Frank and Gwen talk suffering in literature and movies, debate the gender politics of picture books, and hang out with one of our funniest guests ever: Genoveve Stowell, manager of the 53rd Street branch.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: August 8, 2016
posts.text: It's prime beach-reading season! Romance and thrillers climb to the top of the list this week.

posts.title: Book Pairings for Olympic Sports

posts.title: Books in Chelsea Clinton’s DNC Speech
posts.text: Her speech was relatively quick, but Clinton managed to mention multiple books and give a shout-out to the local library of her childhood.

posts.title: One Bad Podcast: The Librarian Is In, Ep. 17
posts.text: Gwen can barely contain herself this week when she and Frank are joined by Biz Ellis, one of the hosts of the One Bad Mother podcast, to talk kids and parents and books. Plus, Biz's 6-year-old daughter makes a book recommendation of her very own!

posts.title: Read 20 Minutes a Day? Finish Moby-Dick before Fall
posts.text: Twenty minutes a day. That's all it takes for kids and adults alike to avoid a summer reading slump... and, as it turns out, to read some really amazing books. So, with our Summer Reading Challenge in full swing, we decided to do a little math.

posts.title: Picture Books for Working Moms
posts.text: All moms are working hard all the time, and moms who work outside their homes could sometimes use a hand explaining their jobs to their kids and handling their separation anxiety. These picture books do just that.

posts.title: PokeBooks for Pokémon GO
posts.text: As freely available public spaces, libraries hold a special position in the game. This list features books for readers of all ages that capture the experience of finding new things in your familiar surroundings.

posts.title: Hogwarts & Hollywood: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 16
posts.text: Welcome to The Librarian Is In, the New York Public Library's podcast about books, culture, and what to read next.

posts.text: Hit us up for a recommendation on Twitter @NYPLRecommends between 10-11 AM EDT on Friday mornings.

posts.text: Inspired by a reader’s comment on our Angry Birds post, we’re thinking about books where the non-underdogs—a.k.a., those little round pigs with the helmets—wind up on top.

posts.title: Water, Water, Everywhere... Except Not
posts.text: Quite a bit of excellent nonfiction has been written about water scarcity; this list presents recent fiction about dystopian visions of a too-dry future.

posts.text: Amanda Nelson, managing editor of Book Riot and host of BR's own book recommendation podcast, joins Frank and Gwen to discuss book recommendations. (What else?)

posts.text: Frank and Gwen keep it local this week, from a fashion show at Jefferson Market and Open Book Night with Mid-Manhattan's Elizabeth Waters, to a great read about the city's Chintz Age and a karaoke trip around Broadway.

posts.title: Bros, Shakespeare, and Nudity... Not All at the Same Time: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 10

posts.title: Six Picture Books for #Hamilkids
posts.text: Picture books about the founding figures from the worlds of hip-hop and the American Revolution… all of whom were in the room where it happens.

posts.title: 39 Women Journalists Whom We Admire
posts.text: Author Gay Talese stirred the ire of the Internet on Saturday when he reportedly couldn't name a single woman writer who inspired him... so we gave him some suggestions in journalism.

posts.title: What, Wait, What Happened?! The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 9
posts.text: Gwen and Frank discuss books that defy description and throw reality for a loop. Longtime residents of Harlem, Greenwich Village, the Bronx, and more get shout-outs in an interview with NYPL's Alex Kelly about the Library's oral history projects.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: April 10, 2016
posts.text: Secrets? Lies? Sibling rivalries? French mysteries and British romance? Sign us up.

posts.title: Grace Jones and Spelling Bees: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 8
posts.text: Who's ready to relive some traumatic moments from childhood?! We go toe-to-toe with the winner of the tri-library spelling bee: NYPL's very own Rob Kelley.

posts.title: Fiction Set in Pakistan
posts.text: Eleven books for readers of all ages.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: April 3, 2016
posts.text: Venture across the pond this week, as tales of Parisian intrigue and British love stories top the bestsellers' list.

posts.title: Miles to Go Before We Sleep
posts.text: In honor of Robert Frost’s birthday, we asked our book experts for a twist on the poet’s infamous line: What’s a children’s book that deals with exhaustion, parental or otherwise?

posts.title: #FridayReads Roundup: Book Recommendations with Marley Dias of #1000BlackGirlBooks!
posts.text: We'll be joined by Marley Dias, the 11-year-old founder of the amazing #1000BlackGirlBooks, for our Twitter office hours this week.

posts.title: I Want a Garden!
posts.text: Urban gardening books that’ll help you grow some plants even if a sprawling tomato seedling won’t fit in your studio.

posts.title: All the Feels: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 7
posts.text: Earnestness sets in when Singing Children's Librarian Emily Lazio joins us to talk about courage and encouragement, children's classics, and a cool new trend in picture books.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: March 20, 2016
posts.text: A historical thriller set in New York City debuts at No. 1 this week, with wedding romances, British love stories, and scary stories of captivity rounding out the list.

posts.title: Hello Out There…

posts.title: She's Cracking the Case
posts.text: Young-adult fiction is rich with young women who investigate crimes, solve mysteries, and apprentice in magical archives.

posts.title: Far Out, Friends: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 6
posts.text: We're heading back to the '70s this week! Shola Lynch of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture joins us to talk about film, collecting history, and what it's like to hug Bert from Sesame Street.

posts.title: Go, Go, Girl Detectives
posts.text: Eight to 12 year olds are prime candidates for fun detective stories—and Nancy Drew isn’t the only game in town anymore! So we’ve compiled a list of series starring girl sleuths, for kids of any gender.

posts.title: Reading Harder in 2016! Update 1
posts.text: Way back at the end of 2015, a few of us accepted Book Riot’s Read Harder Challenge for the upcoming year. We promised to pop in with periodic updates about our progress, and here’s our first one!

posts.title: LOL-brary Books
posts.text: Eliot may claim that April is the cruelest month, but we’re pretty sure it’s February.

posts.title: Librarians on ‘To Kill a Mockingbird’
posts.text: Personal reflections on Harper Lee's first novel.

posts.title: We Love Men! The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 5
posts.text: Taboo subjects in adult and children's books alike abound on our fifth episode. Plus, find out what makes a "rare book" rare with our very own rare book librarian, Jessica Pigza.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: February 21, 2016
posts.text: This week's list features a mix of heart-pounding thrillers and heart-warming romance.

posts.title: Who's the King of Ohio?
posts.text: Stephen King asked Twitter to come up with great novels about Ohio, and we rose to the challenge.

posts.title: Finding Love in NYC, Literally
posts.text: The city that never sleeps is the backdrop for some of literature’s best love stories. Here are our favorite romantic scenes that take place in the city, plus a map with their locations.

posts.title: The Podcast That Must Not Be Named: The Librarian Is In, Ep. 4
posts.text: Go behind the scenes at BookOps, the Library's special secret spy agent— er, the "technical services" unit. Also: the Helen Ellis/Shirley Jackson/Anita Brookner triumvirate, Frank's shocking Harry Potter confession, and more.

posts.title: The Journalist’s Journey
posts.text: Long-form nonfiction can be a great way to get a behind-the-scenes look at not just the "what" and the "why," but also the "how."

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: January 31, 2016
posts.text: A welcome infusion of new titles this week! A frontier survival story, a steamy romance, a thriller, and a mother-daughter story join the list.

posts.title: Our YA Movie Wishlist
posts.text: Hollywood has officially gone YA, and blockbusters that started as young-adult fiction abound. So, we asked our team of expert librarians for their wishlists: What’s a YA book you’d like to see turned into a movie, and whom would you cast in the leading role?

posts.title: Famous Literary Locales, Visualized
posts.text: Public domain images from Digital Collections that remind us of classic books.

posts.title: Stressed Out? Try a Literary Rx
posts.text: Here’s a selection of recent titles, ranging from personal stories to practical self-help guides, that tackle different approaches to easing our minds and breathing through the stress.

posts.title: #TeamEdith: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 3
posts.text: We talk about how to fit more reading into busy schedules, Lin-Manuel Miranda, horror books and movies, childhood favorites, David Bowie, Lin-Manuel Miranda again, and our love for Downton Abbey’s kind Anna and unstoppable Edith.

posts.title: Following in Winnie's Pawprints
posts.text: Kids cannot live by Winnie-the-Pooh alone, so we asked our picture-book experts here at NYPL to tell us about their favorite stories that feature bears as the protagonists.

posts.title: Move over, Binge-Watching...
posts.text: ... because it's time for some binge-reading. Start some series that you might want to race through the same way you raced through Making a Murderer.

posts.title: Carry On, Carry On...
posts.text: Move over, Harry Potter… there's a new boy wizard in town.

posts.title: Cloning Clooney: The Librarian Is In Podcast, Ep. 2
posts.text: Our brand-new podcast is a sophomore now, and Frank and Gwen are joined by NYPL's very own Jason Baumann. We talk about feminist comics, The Golden Girls, squids and snails, intellectualism, and—yes—cloning George Clooney.

posts.title: Our Most-Recommended Books of 2015
posts.text: Reflecting on the 365234298657 billion books (an exact number) we recommended this past year.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: December 20, 2015
posts.text: No strangers to the top five this week: Kristin Hannah, Jack Ryan, Alex Cross, Harry Bosch, and John Grisham. Welcome back everyone!

posts.title: NYPL's Suggestions for the 2016 Read Harder Challenge
posts.text: Read outside your comfort zone this year! Check out our recommendations for Book Riot's annual challenge.

posts.title: Visit Us in December: The Librarian Is In at NYPL
posts.text: We’re doing a bit of match-making this season at The New York Public Library! It can be daunting trying to figure out what to read next or which book your favorite people want for the holidays—and that’s where we come in.

posts.title: Oh Books, Take Me Away
posts.text: Is the holiday season getting to you? Look no further than your local library to find a quick escape. We asked our expert NYPL staff to name some books that make them want to sneak off to the bathroom, lock the door, and disappear into another world during the holidays.

posts.title: One for Each Night: Chanukah Books for Every Age
posts.text: It's Chanukah already?! Get in the mood for latkes and candles with this Chanukah sampler of eight books—one for each night, and for dreidel-players of all ages.

posts.title: New York Times Read Alikes: December 1, 2015
posts.text: A tricky mystery debuts at No. 1 this week, followed by two more new thrillers lower on the list.

posts.title: Dysfunctional Family Functions
posts.text: Ah, Thanksgiving. Turkey dinners, football games, and lots and lots of family time—so check out some books and plays that feature families coming together for group meals or celebrations that ends in disaster.

posts.title: Let’s Start at the Very Beginning
posts.text: Make the coming winter a little warmer with the first books in romance series that have promising new installments coming out in the next few months.

posts.title: The Essential Board Book Library
posts.text: Board books—those thick little books with the hard pages made of paperboard—can withstand teething, stacking, and the whims of toddlerhood.

posts.title: Telling the Stories of the Trans Community
posts.text: “Write what you know,” they say. So, for TransgenderAwareness Month, we present trans authors (and one author with trans family members) who’ve written memorable trans characters—one book for children, one for young adults, and one for adults.

posts.title: Soldiers’ Stories
posts.text: This Veterans’ Day, when we honor the contributions of the men and women in the U.S. Armed Forces, we’re thinking about books told from the perspective of soldiers, pilots, medical personnel, and everyone who’s served in combat.

posts.title: Staff Picks: A Guide for the Perplexed by Dara Horn
posts.text: Every month, library staff members are bringing you 100 books we love—culled from the millions upon millions out in the world—via our interactive Staff Picks browse tool. This month, we're going with a fantastical novel: A Guide for the Perplexed by Dara Horn.

posts.title: Ask the Author: David Hare
posts.text: David Hare comes to Books at Noon this week to discuss his latest work, The Blue Touch Paper: A Memoir.

posts.title: What’s So Scary about 'The Giving Tree'?
posts.text: We asked our NYPL book experts to name some books that aren’t technically scary—not horror or dystopia or anything else intended to freak you out—but that have some kind of eerie, haunting element they just can’t get out of their heads.

posts.title: Houses of Horror
posts.text: We went in search of some books that would be off the beaten path to the haunted house and asked our NYPL book experts to name some unusual, specific, super-cool sub-genres of horror.

posts.title: Still Curious after 'Curious Incident'?
posts.text: More YA books that echo the sense of mystery and fantastic storytelling of the novel and Broadway show.

posts.title: Prepping for Book Riot Live
posts.text: Get ready—or participate from afar, if you can’t make it to the Big Apple—with books from a few of the event’s featured authors.

posts.title: Ask the Author: Sloane Crosley
posts.text: Sloane Crosley comes to Books at Noon this week to discuss her latest book, The Clasp.

posts.title: Remembering Vera B. Williams

posts.title: Literary Getaways for Teen Read Week

posts.title: Waiting for the National Book Award Finalists? Try These.

posts.title: The Legacy of Charlotte's Web

posts.title: What’s Making Us Happy, Part 2

posts.title: What’s Making Us Happy, Part 1

posts.title: The Gatsby Effect

posts.title: Triple Threats

posts.text: We asked our expert NYPL staff, “What’s your favorite book that features a protagonist with a disability, and why do you like it?”

posts.title: Five Essential Doctorow Reads (Plus Three Surprises)

posts.title: Gamer Books to Read While You Wait for Armada
posts.text: Put Armada on hold, and then come back and check out five other gamer books.

posts.title: Seven New YA Nail-Biters

posts.text: In honor of Jean-Paul Sartre, we present a quiz with a touch of the ridiculous.

posts.title: Summer of STEAM

posts.title: What's Your Literary Waterloo?

posts.title: Going Southern Goth
posts.text: Dark in tone and set in an atmosphere of decay and decline, Southern Gothic lit is colored by that intense, damp, uniquely Southern heat pressing down on its characters and stories.

posts.title: New LGBTQ Picks for Teens
posts.text: NYC Pride is almost here, and we're celebrating with a new crop of books for young members of the LGBTQ community.

posts.title: What Would Olivia Pope Read?
posts.text: It’ll be three long months until Scandal returns to TV. In the meantime, your NYPL librarians picked out some books—science fiction to political thrillers to self-help to romance—that everyone’s favorite D.C. fixer might read to pass the time.

posts.title: Summer of STEM
posts.text: Scientifically minded kids have some great new nonfiction titles to choose from when they’re looking for a summer read.

posts.title: New YA from New Authors
posts.text: An intersex teen, a deadly meteor, and an army of the undead… an impressive collection of writers are making their young-adult debuts with these 10 tantalizing reads.

posts.title: ​For Dads Who Don't Play Golf (Not That There's Anything Wrong with That)
posts.text: If you’re looking for something a little different this year, check out books for a wide variety of dads—as long as they’re readers.

posts.title: Anticipation: YA Summer Releases
posts.text: Can't wait for the new young-adult titles coming out this summer? Put the summer's most popular releases on hold right now and get them the moment they arrive.

posts.title: Dorks, Yoga, and Creepy Vacations: New Summer Picks for 8-to-12 Year Olds
posts.text: Summertime is reading time—and that means the release of eagerly anticipated new installments in beloved series, plus some first-time authors with original offerings.

posts.title: Before You Visit ‘Paper Towns’...
posts.text: Nerdfighters are counting down the days until “Paper Towns”—the movie version of John Green’s 2008 novel, following last summer’s blockbuster version of The Fault In Our Stars —hits theaters on July 24. While you wait to watch Q and co. take their road trip on the big screen, help pass the time with a few other character-driven YA titles with elements of mystery and travel.

posts.title: Up Your Kid-Lit Game
posts.text: Everyone knows Goodnight Moon and Blueberries for Sal, but there’s a world of undiscovered children’s books just waiting for a new audience. This week, NYPL staff recommend pairs of children’s books: a classic plus a newer release, for adults ready to move beyond their own beloved childhood stories.

posts.title: Carver vs. Cheever: Who Said It?
posts.text: Two giants of the American short story and one NYPL quiz. Can you guess who said it?

posts.title: Elementary, My Dear Librarian: Celebrating Arthur Conan Doyle
posts.text: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle is immortal, in a way: He lives on in his most famous character, the detective Sherlock Holmes. NYPL staff picked out their all-time favorite stories about the inimitable detective. (Don’t worry — no spoilers.)

posts.title: Hungry for Peeta? Memorable Secondary Characters in YA
posts.text: Katniss wouldn't have been Katniss without her faithful companion by her side in The Hunger Games.
